title: 109_hr1010
content: CERTAIN MODIFICATIONS PERMITTED TO QUALIFIED MORTGAGES HELD BY A REMIC OR A GRANTOR TRUST. Certain modifications are permitted to qualified mortgages held by a REMIC or a grantor trust. An obligation shall not lose its qualified mortgage status due to a qualified modification, which includes amendments, waivers, or other changes treated as a disposition under section 1001 of the Internal Revenue Code. Certain modifications to qualified mortgages held by a REMIC or grantor trust are allowed without losing qualified mortgage status. Amendments, waivers, or other changes under section 1001 must not extend the final maturity date, increase the principal balance (excluding accrued interest), release real property securing the obligation, or reduce the principal security interest in real property. The regulations allow for modifications to qualified mortgages held by a REMIC or grantor trust without losing qualified mortgage status. Amendments, waivers, or other changes must not extend the final maturity date, increase the principal balance, release real property securing the obligation, or reduce the principal security interest in real property. Amendments to obligations in default or with foreseeable default may be treated as qualified modifications. Defeasance with government securities can satisfy certain requirements. Additionally, Section 672 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a special rule for certain investment trusts regarding qualified modifications. The amendments made by this section apply to modifications made after the enactment of the Act regarding qualified modifications in investment trusts.
